introduction: The Power System Laboratory is designed to provide practical exposure to the fundamental concepts and analytical techniques used in the planning, operation, control, and stability assessment of modern electrical power systems. Through a series of simulation-based experiments, students learn to model power system networks, perform power flow and stability analyses, evaluate system security under contingencies, and understand economic and operational aspects such as loadâ€“frequency control and economic dispatch. This laboratory bridges the gap between theoretical knowledge and real-world power system applications, enabling learners to analyze complex power networks and develop skills essential for power system engineering practice.

experiments.name: Formation of Bus Admittance (YBUS) Matrix of Power System Network
Power Flow Analysis using Gauss-Seidel Method
Power Flow Analysis using Newton-Raphson Method
Power Flow Analysis using Fast Decoupled Method
Transient Stability Analysis for Single Machine Infinite Bus (SMIB) System
Load Frequency Control: Droop Control and Power Sharing
Economic Dispatch using Lambda Iteration Method

objective: To provide students with hands-on experience in modeling, analysis, control, stability assessment, security evaluation, and economic operation of electrical power systems using computational and simulation-based techniques, thereby strengthening their understanding of real-world power system behavior and decision-making processes.
